section.name: AndroMDA Namespace
section.p: AndroMDA namespace components are described through a single XML descriptor, the namespace.xml file. You'll find this file in a cartridge, translation-library or metafacades jar (basically any component that can reside with a namespace) located in the /META-INF/andromda directory of that jar.
In order for a namespace component to be "discovered" by AndroMDA, it MUST be registered within this descriptor.

p.ol:
There are several purposes of the namespace descriptor:
Allowing discovery of the namespace by AndroMDA when placed on the classpath
Providing registration all components for the namespace
Defining any properties that are used to configure the namespace

section.p: Each namespace descriptor must adhere to this XML Schema.

Let's take a look at how a typlical namespace descriptor is structured. You'll notice from this example below that both the cartridge and metafacades components are defined for the webservice namespace. What this means, is that when AndroMDA "discovers" this namepsace, it will know that it needs to register both a cartridge and a set of metafacades under the namespace of webservice (the descriptors for both the cartridge and metafacades will be need to be present in the webservice cartridge jar). Defines the locations to which output is generated. Specifies the directory to which generated WSDL's will be placed. The directory to which any non implementation Java files will be generated. The directory to which any AXIS specific configuration files are generated (such as the WSDD files, etc). The directory to which AXIS specific test classes are generated. The directory to which the AXIS specific test implementation classes are generated. The directory to which any WSS4J specific configuration files are generated. impl Defines the prefix to give to the default namespace. {0} The pattern to use when a qualified name local part is created. {0} represents the name of the classifier (i.e. WS{0} would give all your types and services a prefix of WS). http://{0} The pattern to use when a namespace is created. {0} represents the package name of the classifier (i.e. ws.{0} would prefix all your type and service namespaces with ws.). ... ...
